MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Government Contracts Procedures.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Keating Mr. Keating
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Finance the practices in relation to tenders for Government supplies particularly in regard to whether or not such tenders are open tenders or otherwise; if he will make a statement on whether or not he proposes any changes to bring about a more open situation in that general regard; and the total amount of such tenders for each of the last three years.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. J. Bruton) John Bruton
Speaker.P: Government contracts procedures allow for both open and selective tendering for supply contracts to Government Departments. While the invitation to tender by open advertisement is adopted in most cases, there are instances where it is more practical to invite tenders directly from a predetermined list of firms. Selective tendering or restricted tendering using lists are appropriate to specialist areas where an open invitation to tender would almost certainly result in excessive administrative costs and time delays.

In certain areas therefore, lists of suitable firms have been drawn up from which tenders are invited. Advertisements are placed in the press regularly inviting firms to apply for inclusion on such lists. The lists are frequently revised so that they embrace the maximum possible number of suitable firms.

MainHeading.P: It would be impractical to dispense with this form of tendering. My Department will shortly be issuing a comprehensive document on Government contracts procedures which will regulate tendering for Government business in such a way as to promote open competition and the encouragement of new and previously untried firms. It is intended-that the new procedures will be published so that they will be available to all potential suppliers to Government Departments. It is hoped that this unprecedented step will be of benefit to firms in promoting a better understanding of tendering requirements and thereby result in greater openness in the Government contracts area.
In the time available it was not possible to obtain figures for the total amount of Government supply tenders for each of the last three years.

Speaker.P: (Limerick West) asked the Minister for Social Welfare the present position with regard to an application for unemployment assistance for a person (details supplied) in County Limerick.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: The person concerned claimed unemployment assistance from 22 May 1986 after he had drawn his maximum entitlement of 390 days unemployment benefit. He is being paid unemployment assistance at the appropriate maximum rate payable in his case of £92.35 weekly on the basis of a qualification certificate issued in conjunction with a previous claim in 1978 showing nil means.

His papers were recently referred to a social welfare officer for an up-to-date report of his means and when the inquiries in the matter are completed his case will be submitted to a deciding officer for re-assessment of his means. His entitlement to unemployment assistance will be reviewed in the light of the means assessment. In the meantime, further weekly payments of £92.35 will continue to be made as they become due.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Noonan (Limerick West) Mr. Noonan (Limerick West)
Speaker.P: (Limerick West) asked the Minister for Social Welfare the reason the maximum rate of disability benefit is not being paid to a person (details supplied) in County Limerick.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: The person concerned claimed disability benefit from 23 April 1985. Payment of benefit was not authorised from that date as there were only 23 contributions recorded on his behalf in the 1983-84 year which governed his claim. However, from 6 January 1986, his entitlement to benefit was based on his insurance record in the 1984-85 year. As he has a total of 49 contributions recorded on his behalf in this year, he qualified for payment of benefit at the maximum rate.

MainHeading.P: Due to an administrative error, payment did not issue to the person concerned in respect of his wife, for the period from 6 January 1986 to 10 March 1986. However, all arrears payable in respect of this period have now been issued, less £55 refunded to the Mid Western Health Board in respect of supplementary welfare allowance advanced.
Benefit is now issuing at the weekly rate of £65.10, the maximum rate payable to a married man. All benefit payable has now been issued up to 14 June 1986.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. H. Byrne Mr. H. Byrne
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Social Welfare when unemployment assistance will be granted to a person (details supplied) in County Wexford.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: Following investigation of his unemployment assistance claim, the means of the person concerned were assessed at £67.65 weekly, derived from self-employment. As the means exceeded the maximum rate of unemployment assistance payable in his case, his claim was disallowed.

He recently appealed against the disallowance of his claim and arising from contentions made in support of his appeal, his case has been referred to a social welfare officer for further inquiries. These inquiries will be completed as soon as possible and his case will then be referred to an appeals officer for determination at the earliest available opportunity. His entitlement to unemployment assistance will be reviewed in the light of the outcome of the appeal.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Carey Mr. Carey
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Social Welfare the reason persons (details supplied) in County Clare have not received the family income supplement which they applied for some time ago.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: A claim for family income supplement was received from the persons concerned on 13 May 1986. The claim was disallowed on the grounds that the gross weekly family income as stated on the application form exceeds £160, the maximum amount for entitlement to a supplement in the case of a family with four children. The claimants were notified of the decision and the reason therefore on 5 June 1986.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Hyland Mr. Hyland
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Social Welfare the reason for the reduction in the unemployment assistance claim of a person (details supplied) in County Laois.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: Following a review of his unemployment assistance claim in January 1985, the means of the person concerned were assessed at £41.75 weekly, derived from benefit from his wife's earnings. However, due to an oversight, the revised means were not put into effect until 21 May 1986 after the error was discovered.

The person concerned had been paid unemployment assistance up to 29 May 1986 on the basis of a qualification certificate previously held by him showing means of 30p weekly and he was, accordingly, in receipt of £99.75 weekly, that is the appropriate maximum rate payable in his case of £100.05 less means of 30p. His correct rate of unemployment assistance is £58.30 weekly, that is £100.05 less means of £41.75.

If the person concerned is of the opinion that his circumstances have changed since the last investigation of means it is open to him to apply for a review of his case. A form for this purpose may be obtained at his local office. In the meantime, further weekly payments of £58.30 will continue to be made as they become due.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Leyden Mr. Leyden
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Social Welfare if she will expedite unemployment assistance for a person (details supplied) in County Roscommon.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: Entitlement to unemployment assistance is dependent on the claimant being the holder of a qualification certificate and in order to obtain a qualification certificate a person must satisfy certain conditions including an assessment of means.

MainHeading.P: The unemployment assistance claim of the person concerned from 14 January 1986 was referred to a social welfare officer for investigation of means. Her inquiries, which proved extensive, have now been completed and arrangements are being made to submit the case to a deciding officer for assessment of means, as quickly as possible. His entitlement to unemployment assistance will be determined in the light of the means assessment.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. O'Leary Mr. J. O'Leary
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Social Welfare when unemployment benefit or unemployment assistance will be paid to a person (details supplied) in County Kerry.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mrs. Hussey) Gemma Hussey
Speaker.P: Entitlement to unemployment benefit is subject to the condition that a person must have at least 26 contributions paid or credited as the appropriate rate in the contribution year governing the claim.

The person concerned claimed unemployment benefit from 5 May 1986. Her claim was disallowed on the grounds that she had insufficient contributions paid or credited during the contribution year 6 April 1984 to 5 April 1985 which governed her entitlement to unemployment benefit from 5 May 1986.

She then claimed unemployment assistance and her case was referred to a social welfare officer for investigation of her means. This investigation will be completed as soon as possible and her case will then be submitted to a deciding officer for assessment of means. Her entitlement to unemployment assistance will be determined in the light of the means assessment. The person concerned ceased to sign the unemployed register with effect from 29 May 1986.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - County Galway Land Vesting.

Speaker.hpid: Mrs. Geoghegan-Quinn Mrs. Geoghegan-Quinn
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture the date on which an application for the vesting of land was received from a person (details supplied) in County Galway; the reason for the long delay in having the matter resolved; and when he expects to have a decision on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy
Speaker.P: The application was received on 13 May 1986. Because of the large number of estates awaiting vesting and the limited staff resources available it is not possible to indicate when vesting can be completed in this case.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - County Galway Farm Aid Application.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Kitt Mr. Kitt
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture if a grant under the new farm improvement scheme will be paid to a person (details supplied) in County Galway for slatted house and silage slab, or alternatively that the same rate of grant be paid under the western package.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy
Speaker.P: The application in question falls to be considered under the programme for western development. Before a decision can be made as to grant aid it will be necessary to clarify the position in regard to the permission of adjoining landholders. The local Farm Development Service are communicating with the applicant in the matter.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Land Commission Arrears.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. N. Treacy Mr. N. Treacy
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture the total number of farmers in each county, throughout the country, in arrears to the Irish Land Commission, as at 31 May 1986; the total amount of money due; and if he will make a statement on this urgent serious matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy
Speaker.P: At 30 April 1986 the latest date for which figures are available £2,923,000 was owed by 33,739 farmers. Details by county are not readily available at present but will be furnished to the Deputy as soon as possible.
The main reasons for the arrears are:—

MainHeading.P: (i) high annuities resulting from the high prices that had to be paid for land by the Land Commission in the late seventies and early eighties together with high interest rates which prevailed at the time.
(ii) poor weather conditions over the past year;
(iii) overborrowing in certain cases from the lending institutions.
Where a farmer in arrears is in serious financial difficulties, the Land Commission is prepared to make some arrangement with him for payment.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Agricultural Incomes.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Leonard Mr. Leonard
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Agriculture the amount received to date, under EC Regulation 797/85, for the improvement of agricultural incomes in the depressed regions.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture (Mr. Deasy) Austin Deasy
Speaker.P: Recoupment is available from FEOGA one year in arrears in respect of a percentage of eligible expenditure by member states under EC Regulation 797/85 on aids to investment undertaken in plans designed to improve farm incomes. The first claim in respect of 1986 expenditure will be forwarded to the EC early in 1987.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Speed of Articulated Trucks.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. S. Byrne Mr. S. Byrne
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice if he is aware of the growing concern with regard to the speed of articulated trucks; if he will take whatever action is necessary to ensure the law is observed in this area; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Dukes) Alan Dukes
Speaker.P: I am informed by the Garda authorities that they receive occasional complaints of alleged breaches of the speed limits by articulated trucks but I have no indication that there is any widespread increase in public concern about the speed of such trucks. I suggest to the Deputy that if he is aware of any area where speed limits are not being observed, he should bring the matter to the attention of the local Garda.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Campile (Wexford) Garda Station.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. H. Byrne Mr. H. Byrne
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice when a sergeant will be appointed for Campile Garda station, New Ross, County Wexford; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Dukes) Alan Dukes
Speaker.P: The detailed deployment of Garda manpower is a matter for the Garda authorities who have informed me that a sergeant will be allocated to Campile station as soon as circumstances permit. I am informed that the policing needs of the area are at present being met by the gardaí attached to Campile station, supported by patrols from the Garda district headquarters at New Ross.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Ballina Garda Patrol.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Calleary Mr. Calleary
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice the steps he proposes to take to prevent a recurrence of the scenes at Knockaskeagh, Ballina; if he will augment Garda strength in Ballina; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Calleary Mr. Calleary
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice the back-up service available to Ballina district in the event of the Garda patrol car stationed there being unable to carry out, for any reason, the necessary patrols.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Dukes) Alan Dukes
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 77 and 78 together. The arrangements for the policing of individual areas are a matter for the Garda authorities having regard to their assessment of needs, overall resources and other demands on Garda services.

MainHeading.P: The authorities report that the current Garda strength at Ballina station is considered adequate to meet the normal policing needs of the Ballina area and that there are arrangements whereby the gardaí at Ballina can seek assistance from the adjoining Garda districts to meet any particular need for manpower or transport which may arise.

As regards the particular incident referred to in Question No. 77, the Garda authorities report that three members of the station party at Ballina went to the scene in the local patrol car immediately they were called and, when it emerged that extra resources were needed to deal with the situation, these were provided by a local inspector and sergeant and the patrol cars from Castlebar and Swinford. The Garda authorities are satisfied that the situation was dealt with effectively on that occasion and that there are adequate arrangements to deal with any such incident.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Calleary Mr. Calleary
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Justice if he will make a statement in relation to the regulations or rulings that prohibit a replacement for an observer in a Garda car if that regular observer is taken ill, attending court or unable for any other reason to carry out normal duties; and if this applies in County Mayo and in the Ballina district; if he is aware that this ruling has meant that a Garda car was not available for duty.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mr. Dukes) Alan Dukes
Speaker.P: Internal Garda regulations relating to the manning and use of patrol cars are a matter for the Garda authorities. They have informed me that there is no regulation or instruction which prohibits the replacement of a member rostered for duty as an observer in a Garda car if such a member is not available for duty, and that there is no record of the patrol car at Ballina being unavailable recently due to the absence of an observer.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - County Roscommon School.

Speaker.hpid: Miss Harney Miss Harney
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if he will agree to retain Rathcroghan national school, Ballinagare, Castlerea, County Roscommon as a two teacher school in view of the circumstances which exist in the area.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. Cooney) Minister for Education (Mr. Cooney)
Speaker.P: In order to retain the assistant teacher in this school an average enrolment of 28 would need to be secured for the quarter ending 30 June 1986. It would not be open to me to waive the requirements of the rules in a particular case.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - County Monaghan Vocational Schools.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Leonard Mr. J. Leonard
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education when the proposed extension to the Carrickmacross, County Monaghan VEC school will be going to tender.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. Cooney) Minister for Education (Mr. Cooney)
Speaker.P: The proposed extension to Carrickmacross vocational school is one of a number of post primary school building projects at bills of quantities stage. A review of all such projects is being carried out at present to establish when they may proceed to the stage of seeking tenders. This review involved monitoring the flow of expenditure on ongoing contractual commitments in relation to available capital.
The County Monaghan Vocational Education Committee will be informed as soon as it becomes possible to sanction the seeking of tenders in this case.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. J. Leonard Mr. J. Leonard
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if he will give an early assurance that an extension to the Ballybay VEC school will be provided, in view of the fact that it is the only second level establishment in that area.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. Cooney) Minister for Education (Mr. Cooney)
Speaker.P: My Department is at present examining an application from County Monaghan Vocational Education Committee for an extension to Ballybay vocational school. I have directed that this examination be brought to finality without delay.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Dublin Secondary Schools.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Gregory-Independent Mr. Gregory-Independent
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if he is aware of the need for a girl's secondary school (junior cycle) in the north city areas of Ballybough, North Strand, East Wall and district, Dublin 3; if he has received representations from the management of St. Vincent's school, North William Street, Dublin 1, for assistance to build a secondary school; if he will consider a response to the local demand for a school; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. Cooney) Minister for Education (Mr. Cooney)
Speaker.P: My Department has not received any proposals in recent years for the provision of a girls secondary school in the Ballybough — North Strand — East Wall area. If an application is received it will be given full consideration. However, I should point out that the existing post primary schools in the general area and the proposed new north inner city vocational school will between them have sufficient accommodation to serve the needs of the pupils in question.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Mayo Schools.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Calleary Mr. Calleary
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if he is aware of the damage to Glenmore national school arising from the recent storms; and if he is in a position to state when work will commence on the building so that all repairs can be carried out during the summer holiday period.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. Cooney) Minister for Education (Mr. Cooney)
Speaker.P: My Department is in receipt of an application from the authorities of Glenmore national school, County Mayo, for a grant for the provision of floor covering. On a recent inspection of the school building by my Department's professional advisers it was found that a costly and extensive scheme of works would be required to bring the school building up to a reasonable standard, including the replacement of the floors and ceilings and improvements to the roof and external playspace. It will accordingly be necessary to have consultations with the school authorities having regard to my Department's policy on not replacing two teacher schools except in circumstances where no suitable alternative provision can be made for the education of the children. These consultations will be concluded at the earliest possible date and a decision on the question of improvements to the existing school buildings will be conveyed to the school authorities as soon as possible thereafter. Representations have not been made by the school that there has been recent storm damage, but I should point out that the cost of repairing such damage is normally covered by insurance.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Calleary Mr. Calleary
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if he will make a statement in relation to Eskeragh national school, Ballina, County Mayo; when work will resume; and the extra accommodation and work which will take place there.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. Cooney) Minister for Education (Mr. Cooney)
Speaker.P: My Department has agreed to grant aid an improvement scheme to Eskeragh national school, Ballina, County Mayo. The scheme has been substantially completed. The scheme included, among other items, the provision of a new toilet block and a quotation for this is awaited. Subject to receipt of an acceptable quotation, the completion of the works will be authorised.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Calleary Mr. Calleary
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if he will make a statement on the up-to-date position in relation to the provision of badly needed accommodation and ancillary works to Crossmolina girls national school; and when work will commence on this project.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. Cooney) Minister for Education (Mr. Cooney)
Speaker.P: My Department has agreed to grant aid the extension of Crossmolina girls national school, County Mayo. The school currently has a staff of eight teachers, including the principal and a remedial teacher, and the accommodation consists of six classrooms and a general purposes area. The sketch scheme was designed by the Office of Public Works. Because the project involves provision of additional classroom accommodation and my Department is unable immediately to undertake preparation of the contract documents, consideration is being given to a request from the school authorities that they be allowed to engage their own architect for this work. A decision in the matter will be conveyed to the school authorities as soon as possible.
It is not possible at this stage to say when building work will commence.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Calleary Mr. Calleary
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if he is aware of the very serious situation that exists at Crossmolina boys national school; and the steps that he intends to take to give priority to the provision of extra accommodation at this school.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. Cooney) Minister for Education (Mr. Cooney)
Speaker.P: My Department has agreed to grant aid the provision of a general purposes room for Crossmolina boys national school, County Mayo. The school has a staff of a principal teacher and three assistant teachers and the accommodation consists of four permanent classrooms.

A sketch scheme has already been prepared for the project. Because of the large number of cases at various stages of architectural planning, it will not be possible for my Department's professional advisers to complete the contract documents in this case for some months at least.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Calleary Mr. Calleary
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education if he is aware of the serious situation that exists at Ballycastle national school; when work will commence on the new national school there; and the steps he proposes to take to expedite the commencement of this project.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. Cooney) Minister for Education (Mr. Cooney)
Speaker.P: My Department has agreed in principle to grant aid the erection of a new building for Ballycastle national school, County Mayo. Because of the large number of projects at various stages of architectural planning, it has not yet been possible for my Department's professional advisers to complete a sketch scheme in this case. My Department had hoped for better progress on the architectural planning of this school, but this has not proved possible because of the volume of work in hands.
I am not in a position at this stage when work on the project will commence.

Speaker.hpid: Mr. Calleary Mr. Calleary
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Education the steps he proposes to take to finalise the provision of extra accommodation to replace an old prefabricated building of Cuilacraun national school, Castlehill, Bellies; and when work will commence on this project.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. Cooney) Minister for Education (Mr. Cooney)
Speaker.P: The Deputy's question is taken to refer to the two teacher Cuilagurrain national school, County Mayo, the authorities of which had asked my Department to consider the result of an architectural survey which they had carried out on the school building. The survey included an estimate of the cost of carrying out the following works: provision of tarmac play areas, replacement of gutters, overhauling of roof, replacement of lights, provision of shelving, insulation of the roof and attention to floors. A subsequent inspection carried out by my Department's professional advisers revealed that a much costlier and more extensive scheme of works would be required to bring the school up to a reasonable standard. It will accordingly be necessary to have further consultation with the school authorities having regard to my Department's policy of not replacing two teacher schools except in circumstances where no suitable alternative provision can be made for the education of the children. These consultations will be concluded at the earliest possible date and a decision on the question of improvements to the existing school buildings will be conveyed to the school authorities as soon as possible thereafter.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Social Employment Scheme.

Speaker.hpid: Dr. O'Hanlon Dr. O'Hanlon
Speaker.P: asked the Minister for Labour the reason a person (details supplied) in County Monaghan has not been employed under the social employment scheme.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Labour (Mr. Quinn) Ruairí Quinn
Speaker.P: The person concerned recently indicated his interest in taking part in the social employment scheme to the National Manpower Service. He is now employed on an SES project with Monaghan County Council.
